 64    @final
 65    def grad(self, x: "Variable", new_names: Optional[dict[str, str]] = None) -> "Tensor":
 66        """
 67        Take the derivative of this tensor with respect to the variable x.
 68
 69        Args:
 70            x: The variable to take the derivative with respect to.
 71            new_names: Optional list of names to use for the new edges created by the derivative.
 72                If not provided, new names will be generated based on the edges of x.
 73
 74        Note:
 75            Pushes the derivative one step through the tensor.
 76            If you want to push it all the way through, use .simplify().
 77
 78        Returns:
 79            The tensor representing the derivative.
 80        """
 81
 82        new_names = self._check_grad(x, new_names)
 83        result = self._grad(x, new_names)
 84
 85        # Check that the shape is preserved
 86        assert result.shape == self.shape | {n: x.shape[o] for o, n in new_names.items()}
 87
 88        return result
 89
 90    def _check_grad(self, x: "Variable", new_names: dict[str, str]) -> dict[str, Symbol]:
 91        # When taking a derivative with respect to a variable, we need some edge names for the derivative.
 92        # If new_names is not given, we generate names based on the edge names of x.
 93        # However, we need to make sure they don't clash with any names already present in the tensor.
 94        # If new_names is already given, we just check to make sure they are not already present in the tensor.
 95        if new_names is not None:
 96            if x.edges != new_names.keys():
 97                raise ValueError(f"The {new_names.keys()=} must match {x.edges=}")
 98            # Check that the new names don't clash with self.edges
 99            if used := self.edges & new_names.values():
100                raise ValueError(f"{used} are already present in {self.edges=}")
101            return new_names
102
103        # Make new names that are _based_ on x.edges and _avoid_ self.edges
104        return _unused_edge_names(x.edges, self.edges)
105
106    def _grad(self, x: "Variable", new_names: dict[str, str]) -> "Tensor":
107        # Override this method to implement differentiation
108        raise NotImplementedError(f"Derivative not implemented for {type(self)}")

110    @final
111    def rename(self, **kwargs: str) -> "Tensor":
112        """
113        Rename free edges of this tensor.
114
115        Args:
116            kwargs: A dictionary mapping old edge names to new edge names.
117                Only free edges can be renamed. Inner edges may get renamed
118                if necessary to avoid clashes with the new free edge names.
119
120        Returns:
121            A new tensor with the edges renamed according to kwargs.
122        """
123
124        # Check that the renaming is valid, and return the renaming dictionary.
125        if len({kwargs.get(e, e) for e in self.edges}) != len(self.edges):
126            raise ValueError(f"Renamed an edge to an existing edge name. {self.edges=} {kwargs=}")
127
128        # Restrict renaming to free edges
129        kwargs = {new: old for new, old in kwargs.items() if new in self.edges}
130
131        result = self._rename(**kwargs)
132
133        # Check that the shape is preserved
134        assert result.shape == {kwargs.get(e, e): s for e, s in self.shape.items()}
135
136        return result

142    @final
143    def simplify(self, args: dict[str, Any] = None) -> "Tensor":
144        """
145        Apply simplification rules to this tensor.
146
147        This may rename inner edges but should never change the free edges.
148
149        Args:
150            args: Optional dictionary of arguments controlling the simplification.
151
152        Returns:
153            A simplified version of this tensor.
154        """
155
156        if args is None:
157            args = {}
158        # args["grad_steps"] allows us to control how far we propagate the derivative.
159        args.setdefault("grad_steps", float("inf"))
160        args.setdefault("associative_products", True)
161        args.setdefault("associative_sums", True)
162        args.setdefault("sum_combine_terms", True)
163        args.setdefault("combine_products", True)
164        args.setdefault("factor_components", True)
165        args.setdefault("expand_functions", True)
166        args.setdefault("expand", False)
167
168        result = self._simplify(args)
169
170        # Check that the shape is preserved
171        assert result.shape == self.shape
172
173        return result

175    def _simplify(self, args: dict[str, Any]) -> "Tensor":
176        # Override this method to implement simplification
177        return self
178
179    def full_simplify(self, expand=True) -> "Tensor":
180        """Applies multiple simplification rules until the expression no longer changes"""
181        expr = self
182        while (new := expr.simplify()) != expr:
183            expr = new
184        if expand:
185            expr = expr.simplify({"expand": True})
186            while (new := expr.simplify({"expand": True})) != expr:
187                expr = new
188        return expr
189
190    @final
191    def substitute(self, x: "Variable", y: "Tensor") -> "Tensor":
192        """Substitute a variable with a tensor"""
193        # Ideally we'd like y to be able to have extra edges that are not in x
194        # but which will be broadcasted as new edges of the tensor. This will
195        # allow us to implement numerical expectation, and other situations where
196        # we originally didn't have broadcasting, but we want to add it.
197        # Maybe we could even remove broadcasted edges of x as well.
198        # The tricky thing is to ensure it doesn't clash with the existing edges.
199        return self._substitute(x, y)

208    @cached_property
209    def weisfeiler_lehman(self) -> str:
210        """Hexadecimal string for WL-hash of the input graph."""
211        G, _ = self.edge_structural_graph(match_edges=False)
212        return nx.algorithms.weisfeiler_lehman_graph_hash(G, node_attr="name")

223    def structural_graph(self) -> tuple[nx.MultiDiGraph, dict[str, int]]:
224        """Create a graph representation of the tensor, which can be used for isomorphism testing.
225
226        Returns:
227            A tuple with the following values:
228            - A NetworkX directed graph.
229                - Each node in the top tree is labeled with the producing tensor.
230                - Use name=hashable to label vertices
231            - "edges", a dict of edge_name -> node id
232            - Node 0 should be the root
233        """
234        raise NotImplementedError
235
236    def edge_structural_graph(
237        self, match_edges: bool = True, edge_names: Optional[dict[str, str]] = None
238    ) -> tuple[nx.MultiDiGraph, list[str]]:
239        """
240        Build a structural graph of the tensor with dummy nodes for outer edges.
241
242        Args:
243            match_edges: If True the names are used to match edges.
244            edge_names: An optional mapping of edge names.
245
246        Returns:
247            A tuple (G, edge_list) where G is the graph and edge_list is the list of edge names.
248        """
249        if edge_names is None:
250            edge_names = {}
251
252        G, edges = self.structural_graph()
253
254        for e in edges.keys():
255            if e not in edge_names:
256                edge_names[e] = ("Outer Edge", e) if match_edges else ""
257
258        for e, node in edges.items():
259            n = G.number_of_nodes()
260            G.add_node(n, name=edge_names[e])
261            G.add_edge(node, n)
262        return G, list(edges.keys())
263
264    def graph_to_string(self) -> str:
265        """
266        Returns an ASCII tree-like representation of the structural graph.
267
268        Returns:
269            A string showing the graph structure.
270        """
271        G, _ = self.edge_structural_graph(match_edges=True)
272        return "\n".join(nx.generate_network_text(G, with_labels="name", sources=[0]))

274    # Overloaded operators
275
276    def __add__(self, other: Union[Number, "Tensor"]) -> "Tensor":
277        w = 1
278        if isinstance(other, Number):
279            other, w = Product([]), other
280        return Sum([self, other], [1, w])
281
282    def __radd__(self, other: Union[Number, "Tensor"]) -> "Tensor":
283        return self + other
284
285    def __rsub__(self, other: Union[Number, "Tensor"]) -> "Tensor":
286        # Handle `other - self`
287        return -self + other
288
289    def __sub__(self, other: Union[Number, "Tensor"]) -> "Tensor":
290        # Handle `self - other`
291        w = 1
292        if isinstance(other, Number):
293            other, w = Product([]), other
294        return Sum([self, other], [1, -w])
295
296    def __neg__(self) -> "Tensor":
297        return Sum([self], [-1])
298
299    def __matmul__(self, other: Union[Number, "Tensor"]) -> "Tensor":
300        if isinstance(other, Number):
301            other = Sum([Product([])], [other])
302        return Product([self, other])
303
304    def __rmatmul__(self, other: Union[Number, "Tensor"]) -> "Tensor":
305        if isinstance(other, Number):
306            return self * other
307        return self @ other
308
309    def __rmul__(self, other: Union[Number, "Tensor"]) -> "Tensor":
310        return self * other
311
312    def __mul__(self, other: Union[Number, "Tensor"]) -> "Tensor":
313        """
314        Contract self with other using tensor product and contraction rules.
315        """
316        if isinstance(other, Number):
317            if other == 0:
318                return Zero(**self.shape)
319            if other == 1:
320                return self
321            return Sum([self], [other])
322
323        from tensorgrad.functions import prod  # Avoid circular import
324
325        return prod(self, other)
326
327    def __rtruediv__(self, other: Union[Number, "Tensor"]) -> "Tensor":
328        # Handle other / self
329        from tensorgrad.functions import pow  # Avoid circular import
330
331        return other * pow(self, -1)
332
333    def __truediv__(self, other: Union[Rational, "Tensor"]) -> "Tensor":
334        # Handle self / other
335        from tensorgrad.functions import pow  # Avoid circular import
336
337        if isinstance(other, int):
338            return Sum([self], [Fraction(1, other)])
339        if isinstance(other, Number):
340            return Sum([self], [1 / other])
341        return self * pow(other, -1)
342
343    def __pow__(self, other: Number) -> "Tensor":
344        from tensorgrad.functions import pow  # Avoid circular import
345
346        if not isinstance(other, (int, Fraction)):
347            raise ValueError("Only integer and fractional powers are supported.")
348        return pow(self, other)
349
350    def is_isomorphic(
351        self, other: "Tensor", match_edges: bool = False, edge_names: None | dict[str, str] = None
352    ) -> bool:
353        """
354        Test whether this tensor is isomorphic to another tensor.
355
356        Args:
357            other: The tensor to compare with.
358            match_edges: Whether to require a matching of edge names.
359            edge_names: Optional mapping to use for edge renaming.
360
361        Returns:
362            True if the tensors are isomorphic; False otherwise.
363        """
364        if self.weisfeiler_lehman != other.weisfeiler_lehman:
365            return False
366        G1, _ = self.edge_structural_graph(match_edges=match_edges, edge_names=edge_names)
367        G2, _ = other.edge_structural_graph(match_edges=match_edges, edge_names=edge_names)
368        return nx.is_isomorphic(G1, G2, node_match=lambda n1, n2: n1.get("name") == n2.get("name"))
369        # return nx.vf2pp_is_isomorphic(G1, G2, node_label="name")
370
371    def isomorphisms(self, other: "Tensor") -> Generator[dict[str, str], None, None]:
372        """
373        Yield all isomorphisms (edge renamings) between self and other.
374
375        Args:
376            other: The other tensor to compare.
377
378        Yields:
379            Dictionaries mapping edge names in self to edge names in other.
380        """
381        G1, edges1 = self.edge_structural_graph(match_edges=False)
382        G2, edges2 = other.edge_structural_graph(match_edges=False)
383        for matching in nx.algorithms.isomorphism.MultiDiGraphMatcher(
384            G1, G2, node_match=lambda n1, n2: n1.get("name") == n2.get("name")
385        ).isomorphisms_iter():
386            # Matching is a dict {i: j} where i is the node in G1 and j is the node in G2
387            # We are only interested in then `len(self.edges)` last nodes, which correspond to the outer edges
388            start_i = G1.number_of_nodes() - len(self.edges)
389            start_j = G2.number_of_nodes() - len(self.edges)
390            yield {
391                edges1[i - start_i]: edges2[j - start_j]
392                for i, j in matching.items()
393                if i >= start_i and j >= start_j
394            }
395
396    @cached_property
397    def symmetries(self) -> set[frozenset[str]]:
398        """Return the orbits of the automorphism group of the tensor."""
399        # The orbits are the sets of edges that ever get mapped to each other.
400        G = nx.Graph([(i, j) for mapping in self.isomorphisms(self) for i, j in mapping.items()])
401        symmetries = set(map(frozenset, nx.connected_components(G)))
402        if hasattr(self, "_symmetries"):
403            assert symmetries == self._symmetries, f"{symmetries=} {self._symmetries=}"
404        return symmetries
405
406    @staticmethod
407    def _check_edges(edges: Iterable[str]) -> list[str]:
408        """
409        Validate and standardize an iterable of edge names.
410
411        Args:
412            edges: An iterable of edge names.
413
414        Returns:
415            A list of edge names.
416
417        Raises:
418            ValueError: If any edge is not a string.
419        """
420        if not isinstance(edges, Iterable):
421            raise ValueError("Edges must be an iterable of strings")
422        edges = list(edges)
423        if not all(isinstance(e, str) for e in edges):
424            raise ValueError("Edges must be an iterable of strings")
425        if len(edges) == 1:
426            edges = edges[0].split(",")
427            return [e.strip() for e in edges]
428        return edges
429
430    @staticmethod
431    def _check_shape(shape0: Iterable[Symbol], shape1: dict[str, Symbol]) -> dict[str, Symbol]:
432        """
433        Check and merge a shape given as an iterable and a dict.
434
435        Args:
436            shape0: An iterable of Sympy symbols.
437            shape1: A dictionary mapping edge names to Sympy symbols.
438
439        Returns:
440            A dictionary merging the two representations.
441
442        Raises:
443            ValueError: If inputs are not of the expected types.
444        """
445        shape0 = tuple(shape0)
446        if not isinstance(shape0, tuple) or not all(isinstance(s, Symbol) for s in shape0):
447            raise ValueError("Shape0 must be a tuple of sympy symbols")
448        if not isinstance(shape1, dict) or not all(isinstance(s, Symbol) for s in shape1.values()):
449            raise ValueError("Shape1 must be a dict of sympy symbols")
450        # Check for duplicate positional dimension names
451        names = [s.name for s in shape0]
452        duplicates = {n for n in names if names.count(n) > 1}
453        if duplicates:
454            raise ValueError(f"Duplicate positional dimension names: {duplicates}")
455        shape0 = {s.name: s for s in shape0}
456        if double_keys := shape0.keys() & shape1.keys():
457            raise ValueError(f"Duplicate edge names: {double_keys}")
458        return shape0 | shape1
459
460    @staticmethod
461    def _check_symmetries(
462        shape: dict[str, Symbol], symmetries: Union[str, set[frozenset[str]], None]
463    ) -> set[frozenset[str]]:
464        """
465        Validate the symmetries for a tensor.
466
467        Args:
468            shape: A dictionary mapping edge names to sizes.
469            symmetries: Either a string (with groups separated by commas) or a set of frozensets.
470
471        Returns:
472            A set of frozensets representing the symmetry groups.
473
474        Raises:
475            ValueError: If the symmetries are inconsistent with the shape.
476        """
477        if symmetries is None:
478            return {frozenset({e}) for e in shape.keys()}
479        if isinstance(symmetries, str):
480            symmetries = {frozenset(word.split()) for word in symmetries.split(",")}
481        # Check symmetries are sets of strings
482        assert all(isinstance(e, str) for group in symmetries for e in group), f"{symmetries=}"
483        if len({e for group in symmetries for e in group}) != len(shape):
484            raise ValueError("Symmetry groups must contain all edges")
485        # Check symmetries are compatible with shape
486        for group in symmetries:
487            if any(e not in shape for e in group):
488                raise ValueError(f"Symmetry group {group} contains edges not in shape")
489            if len({shape[e] for e in group}) != 1:
490                raise ValueError(f"Symmetry group {group} must all have same dim size")
491        return symmetries

def full_simplify(self, expand=True) -> Tensor: 
179    def full_simplify(self, expand=True) -> "Tensor":
180        """Applies multiple simplification rules until the expression no longer changes"""
181        expr = self
182        while (new := expr.simplify()) != expr:
183            expr = new
184        if expand:
185            expr = expr.simplify({"expand": True})
186            while (new := expr.simplify({"expand": True})) != expr:
187                expr = new
188        return expr

Applies multiple simplification rules until the expression no longer changes

@final
def substitute( self, x: Variable, y: Tensor) -> Tensor: 
190    @final
191    def substitute(self, x: "Variable", y: "Tensor") -> "Tensor":
192        """Substitute a variable with a tensor"""
193        # Ideally we'd like y to be able to have extra edges that are not in x
194        # but which will be broadcasted as new edges of the tensor. This will
195        # allow us to implement numerical expectation, and other situations where
196        # we originally didn't have broadcasting, but we want to add it.
197        # Maybe we could even remove broadcasted edges of x as well.
198        # The tricky thing is to ensure it doesn't clash with the existing edges.
199        return self._substitute(x, y)

Substitute a variable with a tensor

def edge_structural_graph( self, match_edges: bool = True, edge_names: Optional[dict[str, str]] = None) -> tuple[networkx.classes.multidigraph.MultiDiGraph, list[str]]: 
236    def edge_structural_graph(
237        self, match_edges: bool = True, edge_names: Optional[dict[str, str]] = None
238    ) -> tuple[nx.MultiDiGraph, list[str]]:
239        """
240        Build a structural graph of the tensor with dummy nodes for outer edges.
241
242        Args:
243            match_edges: If True the names are used to match edges.
244            edge_names: An optional mapping of edge names.
245
246        Returns:
247            A tuple (G, edge_list) where G is the graph and edge_list is the list of edge names.
248        """
249        if edge_names is None:
250            edge_names = {}
251
252        G, edges = self.structural_graph()
253
254        for e in edges.keys():
255            if e not in edge_names:
256                edge_names[e] = ("Outer Edge", e) if match_edges else ""
257
258        for e, node in edges.items():
259            n = G.number_of_nodes()
260            G.add_node(n, name=edge_names[e])
261            G.add_edge(node, n)
262        return G, list(edges.keys())

Build a structural graph of the tensor with dummy nodes for outer edges.

Args: match_edges: If True the names are used to match edges. edge_names: An optional mapping of edge names.

Returns: A tuple (G, edge_list) where G is the graph and edge_list is the list of edge names.

def graph_to_string(self) -> str: 
264    def graph_to_string(self) -> str:
265        """
266        Returns an ASCII tree-like representation of the structural graph.
267
268        Returns:
269            A string showing the graph structure.
270        """
271        G, _ = self.edge_structural_graph(match_edges=True)
272        return "\n".join(nx.generate_network_text(G, with_labels="name", sources=[0]))

def is_isomorphic( self, other: Tensor, match_edges: bool = False, edge_names: None | dict[str, str] = None) -> bool: 
350    def is_isomorphic(
351        self, other: "Tensor", match_edges: bool = False, edge_names: None | dict[str, str] = None
352    ) -> bool:
353        """
354        Test whether this tensor is isomorphic to another tensor.
355
356        Args:
357            other: The tensor to compare with.
358            match_edges: Whether to require a matching of edge names.
359            edge_names: Optional mapping to use for edge renaming.
360
361        Returns:
362            True if the tensors are isomorphic; False otherwise.
363        """
364        if self.weisfeiler_lehman != other.weisfeiler_lehman:
365            return False
366        G1, _ = self.edge_structural_graph(match_edges=match_edges, edge_names=edge_names)
367        G2, _ = other.edge_structural_graph(match_edges=match_edges, edge_names=edge_names)
368        return nx.is_isomorphic(G1, G2, node_match=lambda n1, n2: n1.get("name") == n2.get("name"))
369        # return nx.vf2pp_is_isomorphic(G1, G2, node_label="name")

Test whether this tensor is isomorphic to another tensor.

Args: other: The tensor to compare with. match_edges: Whether to require a matching of edge names. edge_names: Optional mapping to use for edge renaming.

Returns: True if the tensors are isomorphic; False otherwise.

def isomorphisms( self, other: Tensor) -> Generator[dict[str, str], NoneType, NoneType]: 
371    def isomorphisms(self, other: "Tensor") -> Generator[dict[str, str], None, None]:
372        """
373        Yield all isomorphisms (edge renamings) between self and other.
374
375        Args:
376            other: The other tensor to compare.
377
378        Yields:
379            Dictionaries mapping edge names in self to edge names in other.
380        """
381        G1, edges1 = self.edge_structural_graph(match_edges=False)
382        G2, edges2 = other.edge_structural_graph(match_edges=False)
383        for matching in nx.algorithms.isomorphism.MultiDiGraphMatcher(
384            G1, G2, node_match=lambda n1, n2: n1.get("name") == n2.get("name")
385        ).isomorphisms_iter():
386            # Matching is a dict {i: j} where i is the node in G1 and j is the node in G2
387            # We are only interested in then `len(self.edges)` last nodes, which correspond to the outer edges
388            start_i = G1.number_of_nodes() - len(self.edges)
389            start_j = G2.number_of_nodes() - len(self.edges)
390            yield {
391                edges1[i - start_i]: edges2[j - start_j]
392                for i, j in matching.items()
393                if i >= start_i and j >= start_j
394            }

Yield all isomorphisms (edge renamings) between self and other.

Args: other: The other tensor to compare.

Yields: Dictionaries mapping edge names in self to edge names in other.

symmetries: set[frozenset[str]] 
396    @cached_property
397    def symmetries(self) -> set[frozenset[str]]:
398        """Return the orbits of the automorphism group of the tensor."""
399        # The orbits are the sets of edges that ever get mapped to each other.
400        G = nx.Graph([(i, j) for mapping in self.isomorphisms(self) for i, j in mapping.items()])
401        symmetries = set(map(frozenset, nx.connected_components(G)))
402        if hasattr(self, "_symmetries"):
403            assert symmetries == self._symmetries, f"{symmetries=} {self._symmetries=}"
404        return symmetries

Return the orbits of the automorphism group of the tensor.

class Variable(Tensor): 
499class Variable(Tensor):
500    def __init__(
501        self,
502        name: str,
503        *shape0: Symbol,
504        _symmetries: None | str | set[frozenset[str]] = None,
505        **shape1: Symbol,
506    ):
507        """
508        A tensor holding a variable.
509
510        Args:
511            name: The name of the variable.
512            shape0: Positional Sympy symbols for dimensions.
513            _symmetries: Optional symmetries (as a string or set of frozensets).
514            shape1: Keyword arguments for dimensions.
515        """
516        self.name = name
517        self._shape = self._check_shape(shape0, shape1)
518        self._symmetries = self._check_symmetries(self._shape, _symmetries)
519
520    def with_symmetries(self, symmetries: str | set[frozenset[str]]) -> "Variable":
521        return Variable(self.name, **self.shape, _symmetries=symmetries)
522
523    def _grad(self, x: "Variable", new_names: dict[str, str]) -> Tensor:
524        if x == self:
525            # TODO: If X has symmetries, the derivative can actually be more complex than this.
526            # See See 2.8.2 Symmetric in the Cookbook: https://www2.imm.dtu.dk/pubdb/edoc/imm3274.pdf
527            return Product(Delta(s, e, new_names[e]) for e, s in self.shape.items())
528        # Note: We don't need to tell Zero the symmetries, since it's automatically
529        # symmetric in all dimensions that have compatible sizes.
530        return Zero(**(self.shape | {new_names[e]: s for e, s in x.shape.items()}))
531
532    def __repr__(self) -> str:
533        args = [f"\"{self.name}\", {', '.join(self.edges)}"]
534        symmetries = ""
535        if self._symmetries != {frozenset({e}) for e in self.edges}:
536            groups = ", ".join(sorted(" ".join(sorted(group)) for group in self._symmetries))
537            symmetries = f'.with_symmetries("{groups}")'
538        return f"Variable({', '.join(args)}){symmetries}"
539
540    def structural_graph(self) -> tuple[nx.MultiDiGraph, dict[str, int]]:
541        G = nx.MultiDiGraph()
542        G.add_node(0, name=("Variable", self.name), tensor=self)
543        edges = {}
544        # Symmetries are more fine-grained than shapes, since two dims can have
545        # the same size, but not be symmetric. E.g. an assymetric square matrix.
546        # Example of variable with 2 sizes, 3 symmetri orbits and 4 edges:
547        # +-size 1-sym 1-e 1
548        # |  +-----sym 2-e 2
549        # +-size 2-sym 3-e 3
550        #           +----e 4
551        for size in set(self.shape.values()):
552            # Symbols are identified by name and assumptions. We might want to have edges
553            # with the same name but different assumptions, so add the id to the node name.
554            G.add_node(size_node := G.number_of_nodes(), name=(f"size={size.name}", id(size)))
555            G.add_edge(0, size_node)
556            # Find each orbit with the given size (see note above about fine-grained-ness)
557            for orbit in self._symmetries:
558                e, *_ = orbit
559                if self.shape[e] != size:
560                    continue
561                # Orbits are named after the variable edges. This ensures that variables are only
562                # isomoprhic with other variables with the same edge names.
563                orbit_name = " ".join(sorted(orbit))
564                G.add_node(orbit_node := G.number_of_nodes(), name=("Orbit Node", orbit_name))
565                G.add_edge(size_node, orbit_node)
566                # All the free edges point to an orbit node
567                for e in orbit:
568                    edges[e] = orbit_node
569        assert edges.keys() == self.edges
570        return G, edges
571
572    def _simplify(self, args: dict[str, Any]) -> Tensor:
573        return self
574
575    def _rename(self, **kwargs: str) -> Tensor:
576        if not kwargs:
577            return self
578        return Rename(self, kwargs)
579
580    def _substitute(self, x: "Variable", y: "Tensor") -> "Tensor":
581        if x == self:
582            return y
583        return self
584
585    def depends_on(self, x: "Variable") -> bool:
586        return x == self

class Rename(Tensor): 
594class Rename(Tensor):
595    """
596    A tensor that renames the edges of an inner tensor.
597
598    This is used to change free edge names (and sometimes inner edge names)
599    without modifying the underlying contraction.
600    """
601
602    def __init__(self, inner: Tensor, rename: dict[str, str]):
603        """
604        Initialize a Rename tensor.
605
606        Args:
607            inner: The tensor to be renamed.
608            rename: A dictionary mapping old edge names to new names.
609        """
610        self.name = "Rename"
611        self.tensor = inner
612        self.mapping = {k: v for k, v in rename.items() if k != v}
613        self._shape = {rename.get(e, e): s for e, s in inner.shape.items()}
614
615    def __repr__(self) -> str:
616        argstring = ", ".join(f'{k}="{v}"' for k, v in self.mapping.items())
617        return f"{self.tensor}.rename({argstring})"
618
619    def depends_on(self, x: "Variable") -> bool:
620        return self.tensor.depends_on(x)
621
622    def _grad(self, x: "Variable", new_names: dict[str, str]) -> Tensor:
623        # If the new names are used in inner, we need to rename them, and then add the
624        # new names to our own rename dict.
625        middle = _unused_edge_names(new_names.values(), self.edges | self.tensor.edges)
626        middle_names = {o: middle[n] for o, n in new_names.items()}
627        middle_to_new = {middle[n]: n for o, n in new_names.items()}
628        return Rename(self.tensor.grad(x, middle_names), middle_to_new | self.mapping)
629
630    @classmethod
631    def merge_renames(cls, *renames: dict[str, str]) -> dict[str, str]:
632        """
633        Merge several renaming dictionaries into one.
634
635        Args:
636            *renames: Arbitrary number of renaming dictionaries.
637
638        Returns:
639            A single dictionary representing the merged renaming.
640        """
641        merged: dict[str, str] = {}
642        for rename in renames:
643            used = merged.keys() | merged.values()
644            # Apply the rename to the existing chains
645            for o, n in merged.items():
646                merged[o] = rename.get(n, n)
647            # Add new renames
648            for o, n in rename.items():
649                if o not in used:
650                    merged[o] = n
651        return merged
652
653    def _simplify(self, args: dict[str, Any]) -> Tensor:
654        inner = self.tensor.simplify(args)
655        if isinstance(inner, Rename):
656            merged = self.merge_renames(inner.mapping, self.mapping)
657            res = inner.tensor.rename(**merged)
658        else:
659            res = inner.rename(**self.mapping)
660        while isinstance(res, Rename) and not res.mapping:
661            res = res.tensor
662        return res
663
664    def _rename(self, **kwargs: str) -> Tensor:
665        return Rename(self.tensor, self.merge_renames(self.mapping, kwargs))
666
667    def _substitute(self, x: "Variable", y: "Tensor") -> "Tensor":
668        return Rename(self.tensor.substitute(x, y), self.mapping)
669
670    def structural_graph(self) -> tuple[nx.MultiDiGraph, dict[str, int]]:
671        # Rename is the only tensor that doesn't actually create its own node in the graph
672        # This allows Variable(i, j=i).with_symmetries("i j") to be isomorphic to
673        # Rename(Variable(j, i=j).with_symmetries("i j"), {"i": "j", "j": "i"})
674        G, t_edges = self.tensor.structural_graph()
675        edges = {}
676        for o, node in t_edges.items():
677            e = self.mapping.get(o, o)
678            edges[e] = node
679        assert edges.keys() == self.edges
680        return G, edges

688    def __init__(self, *shape0: Symbol, _symmetries: Optional[set[frozenset[str]]] = None, **shape1: Symbol):

690        A constant tensor with the given edges.
691
692        Args:
693            shape0: Positional dimensions (as Sympy symbols).
694            _symmetries: Optional symmetry groups.
695            shape1: Keyword dimensions.
696        """

713            G.add_node(size_node := G.number_of_nodes(), name=f"size={size.name}({id(size)})")
714            G.add_edge(0, size_node)
715            # Find each orbit with the given size (see note above about fine-grained-ness)
716            for orbit in self._symmetries:

718                if self.shape[e] != size:

720                G.add_node(orbit_node := G.number_of_nodes(), name="Orbit Node")

def structural_graph( self) -> tuple[networkx.classes.multidigraph.MultiDiGraph, dict[str, int]]: 
707    def structural_graph(self) -> tuple[nx.MultiDiGraph, dict[str, int]]:
708        G = nx.MultiDiGraph()
709        G.add_node(0, name=type(self).__name__, tensor=self)
710        edges = {}
711        for size in set(self.shape.values()):
712            # All of this is more or less equal to Variable
713            G.add_node(size_node := G.number_of_nodes(), name=f"size={size.name}({id(size)})")
714            G.add_edge(0, size_node)
715            # Find each orbit with the given size (see note above about fine-grained-ness)
716            for orbit in self._symmetries:
717                e, *_ = orbit
718                if self.shape[e] != size:
719                    continue
720                G.add_node(orbit_node := G.number_of_nodes(), name="Orbit Node")
721                G.add_edge(size_node, orbit_node)
722                for e in orbit:
723                    edges[e] = orbit_node
724        return G, edges

class Delta(Constant): 
739class Delta(Constant):
740    """The "Delta" tensor is defined by C_{i,j,k} = 1 if i == j == k, else 0
741    Or alternatively as  =  (e), where are e_i are basis vectors
742    For order 2, this is the identity matrix.
743        Note: For higher order, the identity tensor is the product of n identity matrices,
744        (order 2 Delta's), not the order-n Delta tensor.
745    For order 0, the Delta tensor is defined as |n|, where n is the size/dimension of the tensor.
746    """
747
748    def __init__(self, size: Symbol, *edges: str):
749        """
750        Initialize a Delta tensor.
751
752        Args:
753            size: The size (dimension) of the tensor.
754            edges: The names of the tensor edges.
755        """
756        edges = self._check_edges(edges)
757        super().__init__(**{e: size for e in edges})
758        assert isinstance(size, (Symbol, Number)), "Size must be a sympy symbol"
759        self._size = size
760
761    @property
762    def size(self) -> Symbol:
763        return self._size
764
765    def __repr__(self) -> str:
766        if not self.edges:
767            return f"Delta({self.size})"
768        return f"Delta({self.size}, \"{', '.join(self.edges)}\")"
769
770    def _rename(self, **kwargs: str) -> Tensor:
771        return Delta(self.size, *[kwargs.get(e, e) for e in self.edges])
772
773    @classmethod
774    def simplify_outer(cls, tensors: list[Tensor]) -> list[Tensor]:
775        """Simplifies a list of tensors assumed to be a product."""
776        while True:
777            tensors, done = cls._simplify_step(tensors)
778            if done:
779                break
780        return tensors
781
782    def structural_graph(self) -> tuple[nx.MultiDiGraph, dict[str, int]]:
783        G = nx.MultiDiGraph()
784        G.add_node(0, name=type(self).__name__, tensor=self)
785        G.add_node(size_node := G.number_of_nodes(), name=f"size={self.size.name}({id(self.size)})")
786        G.add_edge(0, size_node)
787        return G, {e: size_node for e in self.edges}
788
789    ################################################################################
790    # There are many simplify rules for Delta. We split them into separate methods for clarity.
791
792    @classmethod
793    def _simplify_step(cls, tensors: list[Tensor]) -> tuple[list[Tensor], bool]:
794        """Performs one step of simplification. Returns a new list if changed, or the original if not."""
795        for e, ts in _group_edges(tensors).items():
796            if len(ts) == 1:
797                continue
798            t1, t2 = ts
799            assert t1.shape[e] == t2.shape[e], f"{t1.shape[e]=} != {t2.shape[e]}, {e=}"
800
801            # Remove t1 and t2 from tensors.  We use the "is" operator, since equality
802            # means isomorphic, so it might remove too many unintended tensors.
803            other = [t for t in tensors if t is not t1 and t is not t2]
804
805            for simplification in [cls._merge_copy_tensors, cls._remove_identity_matrix]:
806                if (new := simplification(t1, t2, e)) is not None:
807                    return other + new, False
808
809        return tensors, True
810
811    @staticmethod
812    def _merge_copy_tensors(t1: Tensor, t2: Tensor, e: str) -> Optional[list[Tensor]]:
813        if not (isinstance(t1, Delta) and isinstance(t2, Delta)):
814            return None
815
816        # We can't merge order 0 copy tensors, since we now give them a value equal to their size.
817        # In principle we could create a new Delta(size1 * size2, []) tensor, but then we start having
818        # arbitrary expressions as sizes, which I'm not sure we want yet.
819        # Also, merging an order 0 with and order > 0 was never going to work, unless the size of the
820        # order 0 Delta was 1, which it probably never is.
821        # In either case, this method should only be called if the tensors share an edge, which they
822        # can't if one of them has order 0.
823        assert t1.order != 0 and t2.order != 0, "Can't merge order 0 Delta tensors"
824
825        # Since the tensors are connected, we can assume they have the same size
826        assert t1.size == t2.size, "Contracted Delta tensors must have same size"
827        size = t1.size
828
829        # We don't just remove e, but remove all shared edges
830        # The amazing thing is that even in the case where all edges disappear, we
831        # still get to keep information on the "size" of the Delta tensor.
832        return [Delta(size, *(t1.edges ^ t2.edges))]
833
834    @staticmethod
835    def _remove_identity_matrix(t1: Tensor, t2: Tensor, e: str) -> Optional[list[Tensor]]:
836        # If both are Delta's, we use the previous method
837        if isinstance(t1, Delta) and isinstance(t2, Delta):
838            return None
839
840        # Make t1 the identity matrix
841        if isinstance(t2, Delta) and t2.order == 2:
842            t1, t2 = t2, t1
843
844        if isinstance(t1, Delta) and t1.order == 2:
845            # Find the edge of t1 that's not e
846            other_edge = next(iter(set(t1.edges) - {e}))
847            # Don't create self loops. We never connect a tensor to itself.
848            # Unless it's another Delta, in which case we already handled it above.
849            if other_edge not in t2.edges:
850                return [t2.rename(**{e: other_edge})]
851        return None

Note: For higher order, the identity tensor is the product of n identity matrices, (order 2 Delta's), not the order-n Delta tensor. For order 0, the Delta tensor is defined as |n|, where n is the size/dimension of the tensor.

@dataclass
class FunctionSignature(abc.ABC): 
 870@dataclass
 871class FunctionSignature(ABC):
 872    """
 873    An abstract base class representing a function that takes one or more tensors as input
 874    and produces a new tensor as output.
 875
 876    This class is designed to capture the symbolic structure of a tensor operation by
 877    listing its output edges (`edges`) and the input edges (`inputs`) each of its input
 878    tensors must provide. Subclasses are required to implement the `eval` and `derivative`
 879    methods, while `simplify` has a default no-op implementation that may be overridden.
 880
 881    Parameters
 882    ----------
 883    name : str
 884        A descriptive name for the function (e.g., "matmul", "unfold", "ce", "attention").
 885    edges : Set[str]
 886        The output edges of this function. These are string identifiers that symbolically
 887        represent the dimensions of the output tensor.
 888    inputs : tuple[Set[str], ...]
 889        A tuple where each element is a set of edges required from one input tensor.
 890        For example, if the first input tensor must share dimension edges {"b", "i"} and
 891        the second input tensor must share dimension edges {"b", "j"}, then
 892        `inputs = ({"b", "i"}, {"b", "j"})`.
 893
 894    Examples
 895    --------
 896    1) **Matrix multiplication**:
 897       Suppose `x` has shape (b, i, j) and `y` has shape (b, j, k). We might define:
 898
 899       .. code-block:: python
 900
 901          f = MatmulSignature(
 902              name="matmul",
 903              edges={"i", "k"},
 904              inputs=({"i", "j"}, {"j", "k"})
 905          )
 906
 907       Here, the function consumes edges `i` and `j` from `x` and edges `j` and `k` from `y`.
 908       The edge `b` is shared between the two inputs and broadcasted. The output tensor
 909       eventually has shape (b, i, k).
 910
 911    2) **Unfold**:
 912       Suppose we have a tensor `x` with shape (b, c, w, h) and we want to produce a series
 913       of patches. We might define:
 914
 915       .. code-block:: python
 916
 917          f = UnfoldSignature(
 918              name="unfold",
 919              edges={"patch", "c_out", "w_out", "h_out"},
 920              inputs=({"c_in", "w_in", "h_in"},)
 921          )
 922
 923       This function consumes edges ``c, w, h`` from `x` and introduces a new edge
 924       named ``patch`` of size (w_in - w_out + 1)*(h_in - h_out + 1).
 925
 926    3) **Cross-entropy**:
 927       This is an example of a function that takes two inputs, for example logits and
 928       probabilities. Suppose:
 929       - `x` has shape (b, logits)
 930       - `y` has shape (b, probs)
 931
 932       We might define:
 933
 934       .. code-block:: python
 935
 936          f = CrossEntropySignature(
 937              name="ce",
 938              edges={"ce"},
 939              inputs=({"logits"}, {"probs"})
 940          )
 941
 942       Both inputs share the batch edge ``b``. The new edge ``ce`` could represent the
 943       cross-entropy output dimension (often scalar per example, so shape (b, ce)).
 944
 945    4) **Multi-query Dot Product Attention**:
 946       Suppose we have tensors:
 947       - `q` with shape (b, n_q, d)
 948       - `k` with shape (b, seq, d)
 949       - `v` with shape (b, seq, d_out)
 950
 951       Conceptually, to compute multi-query attention:
 952
 953       - We form (b, n_q, seq) via a dot product of `q` and `k`.
 954       - We apply a softmax to get (b, n_q, prob).
 955       - We multiply by `v` to get (b, n_q, d_out).
 956
 957       A possible signature might be:
 958
 959       .. code-block:: python
 960
 961          f = AttentionSignature(
 962              name="attention",
 963              edges={"n_q", "d_out"},
 964              inputs=(
 965                  {"n_q", "d"},
 966                  {"seq", "d"},
 967                  {"seq", "d_out"},
 968              )
 969          )
 970
 971       The edge ``b`` is shared among all inputs (broadcast). The final output
 972       has shape (b, n_q, d_out).
 973    """
 974
 975    name: str
 976    # The output edges of the function. Note no Symbols here, since we don't know the sizes yet.
 977    edges: set[str]
 978    # Defines the number of input tensors the function takes, and what edges it needs from each
 979    inputs: tuple[set[str], ...]
 980
 981    # TODO: Functions should support symmetric outputs, just like Constant and Variable.
 982    # Actually we could define symmetries for the inputs too, since the order doesn't always matter.
 983
 984    def derivative(self, i: int, new_edges: dict[str, str] = None) -> "FunctionSignature":
 985        """
 986        Returns a new FunctionSignature that represents the derivative
 987        with respect to the i-th input, and where edges are created
 988        according to `new_edges` a dict {old_name : new_name}.
 989        """
 990        if new_edges is None:
 991            new_edges = {}
 992        if self.inputs[i] != new_edges.keys():
 993            raise ValueError(f"Expected {self.inputs[i]} but got {new_edges.keys()}")
 994        if self.edges & set(new_edges.values()):
 995            raise ValueError(f"New edges {new_edges.values()} clash with {self.edges=}")
 996        return FunctionSignature(f"D_{i}{self.name}", self.edges | set(new_edges.values()), self.inputs)
 997
 998    def simplify(self, t: "Function", args: dict[str, Any]) -> Tensor:
 999        """
1000        Simplifies the Function tensor that uses this signature.
1001        Default implementation returns `t` unchanged.
1002        Subclasses can override this method for custom simplifications.
1003        """
1004        return t
1005
1006    def __repr__(self) -> str:
1007        return f"FunctionSignature('{self.name}', {set(self.edges)}, {[set(s) for s in self.inputs]})"

An abstract base class representing a function that takes one or more tensors as input and produces a new tensor as output.

This class is designed to capture the symbolic structure of a tensor operation by listing its output edges (edges) and the input edges (inputs) each of its input tensors must provide. Subclasses are required to implement the eval and derivative methods, while simplify has a default no-op implementation that may be overridden.

Parameters

name : str A descriptive name for the function (e.g., "matmul", "unfold", "ce", "attention"). edges : Set[str] The output edges of this function. These are string identifiers that symbolically represent the dimensions of the output tensor. inputs : tuple[Set[str], ...] A tuple where each element is a set of edges required from one input tensor. For example, if the first input tensor must share dimension edges {"b", "i"} and the second input tensor must share dimension edges {"b", "j"}, then inputs = ({"b", "i"}, {"b", "j"}).

Examples

1) Matrix multiplication: Suppose x has shape (b, i, j) and y has shape (b, j, k). We might define:

```python f = MatmulSignature( name="matmul", edges={"i", "k"}, inputs=({"i", "j"}, {"j", "k"}) )


   Here, the function consumes edges `i` and `j` from `x` and edges `j` and `k` from `y`.
   The edge `b` is shared between the two inputs and broadcasted. The output tensor
   eventually has shape (b, i, k).

2) **Unfold**:
   Suppose we have a tensor `x` with shape (b, c, w, h) and we want to produce a series
   of patches. We might define:

   ```python
f = UnfoldSignature(
    name="unfold",
    edges={"patch", "c_out", "w_out", "h_out"},
    inputs=({"c_in", "w_in", "h_in"},)
)

This function consumes edges c, w, h from x and introduces a new edge named patch of size (w_in - w_out + 1)*(h_in - h_out + 1).

3) Cross-entropy: This is an example of a function that takes two inputs, for example logits and probabilities. Suppose:

  • x has shape (b, logits)
  • y has shape (b, probs)

We might define:

```python f = CrossEntropySignature( name="ce", edges={"ce"}, inputs=({"logits"}, {"probs"}) )


   Both inputs share the batch edge ``b``. The new edge ``ce`` could represent the
   cross-entropy output dimension (often scalar per example, so shape (b, ce)).

4) **Multi-query Dot Product Attention**:
   Suppose we have tensors:
   - `q` with shape (b, n_q, d)
   - `k` with shape (b, seq, d)
   - `v` with shape (b, seq, d_out)

   Conceptually, to compute multi-query attention:

   - We form (b, n_q, seq) via a dot product of `q` and `k`.
   - We apply a softmax to get (b, n_q, prob).
   - We multiply by `v` to get (b, n_q, d_out).

   A possible signature might be:

   ```python
f = AttentionSignature(
    name="attention",
    edges={"n_q", "d_out"},
    inputs=(
        {"n_q", "d"},
        {"seq", "d"},
        {"seq", "d_out"},
    )
)

The edge b is shared among all inputs (broadcast). The final output has shape (b, n_q, d_out).

class Function(Tensor): 
1038class Function(Tensor):
1039    """
1040    A tensor that represents a function applied to one or more input tensors.
1041
1042    Attributes:
1043        signature: The FunctionSignature for this function.
1044        inputs: A list of input tensors.
1045        shape_out: A dictionary mapping output edge names to sizes.
1046    """
1047
1048    def __init__(
1049        self,
1050        signature: FunctionSignature,
1051        inputs: Iterable[Tensor],
1052        shape_out: dict[str, Symbol],
1053    ):
1054        """
1055        A function tensor that takes one or more input tensors and produces an output tensor.
1056
1057        Args:
1058            signature: The FunctionSignature defining this function, or a string giving the function name.
1059            inputs: The input tensors and their input edge names. [(t0, e00, e01, ...), (t1, e10, ...), ...]
1060            shape_out: The names of the output edges of this function.
1061        """
1062        self.shape_out = self._check_shape([], shape_out)
1063        self.inputs = list(inputs)
1064        self.signature = signature
1065
1066        # Validation
1067        if self.shape_out.keys() != signature.edges:
1068            raise ValueError(f"Signature doesn't match shape: {self.shape_out.keys()=} != {signature.edges}")
1069        if len(self.inputs) != len(signature.inputs):
1070            raise ValueError(f"Expected {len(signature.inputs)} inputs, got {len(self.inputs)}")
1071        for t, es in zip(self.inputs, signature.inputs):
1072            if es - t.edges:
1073                raise ValueError(f"Input edges {es} not subset of {t.edges=}")
1074
1075        # Build final shape = union of output edges + broadcast edges from each input
1076        # Note that this approach pushes all the broadcasted edges to the end of the shape.
1077        # But we don't care about the order of the edges, so it's fine.
1078        self._shape = dict(self.shape_out)
1079        # We allow "broadcasting" for edges that are not in fn_sig.inputs[i].
1080        # So if an input has edges that are not used, they're broadcasted.
1081        for t, es in zip(self.inputs, self.signature.inputs):
1082            # any edges in t.edges - es are "broadcast"
1083            broadcast_edges = t.edges - es
1084            if broadcast_edges & self._shape.keys():
1085                raise ValueError("Broadcast edges must not be shared between inputs")
1086            for b in broadcast_edges:
1087                self._shape[b] = t.shape[b]
1088
1089    def _rename(self, **kwargs: str) -> Tensor:
1090        renamed_inputs = []
1091        for t, es in zip(self.inputs, self.signature.inputs):
1092            # Only rename external edges of input tensors.
1093            rename = {e: v for e, v in kwargs.items() if e not in es}
1094            renamed_inputs.append(t.rename(**rename))
1095        output_rename = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() if k in self.shape_out}
1096        res = Function(
1097            self.signature,
1098            renamed_inputs,
1099            self.shape_out,
1100        )
1101        if output_rename and any(v != k for k, v in output_rename.items()):
1102            res = Rename(res, output_rename)
1103        return res
1104
1105    def _simplify(self, args: dict[str, Any]) -> Tensor:
1106        new_inputs = [t.simplify(args=args) for t in self.inputs]
1107
1108        # Broadcasting can be pulled out of the function.
1109        pulled_out = []
1110        new_inputs2 = []
1111        for t, es in zip(new_inputs, self.signature.inputs):
1112            if isinstance(t, Product):
1113                new_prod = []
1114                for u in t.factors:
1115                    if (
1116                        isinstance(u, Delta)
1117                        and u.order == 1
1118                        and list(u.edges)[0] in t.edges
1119                        and list(u.edges)[0] not in es
1120                    ):
1121                        pulled_out.append(u)
1122                    else:
1123                        new_prod.append(u)
1124                new_inputs2.append(Product(new_prod))
1125            else:
1126                new_inputs2.append(t)
1127        new_inputs = new_inputs2
1128
1129        res = Function(self.signature, new_inputs, self.shape_out)
1130
1131        # This results in an extra simplify call to all the children of the function.
1132        # Maybe we can avoid this somehow?
1133        old_shape = res.shape
1134        res = self.signature.simplify(res, args)
1135        assert res.shape == old_shape, "Function signature simplify should not change shape"
1136
1137        if pulled_out:
1138            res = Product([res] + pulled_out)
1139
1140        return res
1141
1142    def _grad(self, x: Variable, new_names: dict[str, str]) -> Tensor:
1143        # We sum over each input function, just like the normal chain rule:
1144        # d/dx f(g(x), , g(x)) =  (d/dx g(x)) Df(g(x), , g(x))
1145
1146        # D_i adds a new output edge to the function, which is contracted with
1147        # the normal output edge of the tensor. So we need to make sure this doesn't
1148        # clash with an existing output edge of f.
1149        parts = []
1150        for i, (t, input_edges) in enumerate(zip(self.inputs, self.signature.inputs)):
1151            # Take the derivative of the outer function
1152            # We need "connection" edges for each edge in input_edges. Mostly we could just use the same name
1153            # but they need to avoid clashing with "new_names" and the output edges of the tensor.
1154            connection_names = _unused_edge_names(input_edges, self.edges | new_names.values())
1155            # Just like simple calculus, we need the derivative of the outside times the derivative of the inside
1156            outside = Function(
1157                self.signature.derivative(i, connection_names),
1158                self.inputs,
1159                self.shape_out | {connection_names[e]: t.shape[e] for e in input_edges},
1160            )
1161            assert outside.edges == self.edges | connection_names.values()
1162
1163            # The the derivative of the inner function
1164            # We rename the (former) input edges to the connection edges, but keep the remaining edges
1165            # (which are part of self.edges) untouched.
1166            inner = Derivative(t.rename(**connection_names), x, new_names)
1167
1168            # The two parts are then multiplied together on the connection names,
1169            # while broadcasted on their remaining shared edges.
1170            import tensorgrad.functions as F  # Import here to avoid circular import
1171
1172            part = F.sum(outside * inner, connection_names.values())
1173            parts.append(part)
1174        return Sum(parts)
1175
1176    def structural_graph(self) -> tuple[nx.MultiDiGraph, dict[str, int]]:
1177        G = nx.MultiDiGraph()
1178        G.add_node(0, name=(type(self).__name__, self.signature.name), tensor=self)
1179        edges = {}
1180        # (1) We add a node for the "function" tensor itself
1181        # TODO: Why is this needed?
1182        G.add_node(1, name=("f", self.signature.name), tensor=self)
1183        G.add_edge(0, 1)
1184        # (2) We add a node for each output edge
1185        # TODO: We should group out-edges by the size-type, similarly to Variable/Constant
1186        # And of course when we add symmetries to outputs, we need to add that too.
1187        for i, e in enumerate(self.shape_out):
1188            G.add_node(i + 2, name=("Edge Out", e))
1189            G.add_edge(1, i + 2)
1190            edges[e] = i + 2
1191        # (3) And we add nodes for all the input tensors
1192        for i, (t, input_edges) in enumerate(zip(self.inputs, self.signature.inputs)):
1193            # Compute graph from input tensor, and ensure it uses distinct node numbers
1194            # Tag the inputs with {i} since order matters for function inputs.
1195            G, t_edges = _add_structural_graph(G, t, root_edge_label=f"{i}")
1196            # Connect tensor to function. We don't need to label here, since
1197            # the input tensor already has labeled its own edges as much as it needs to.
1198            for e in input_edges:
1199                G.add_edge(t_edges[e], 1)
1200            # Finally register free edges
1201            for e in t.edges:
1202                if e not in input_edges:
1203                    edges[e] = t_edges[e]
1204        return G, edges
1205
1206    def __repr__(self) -> str:
1207        args = []
1208        args.append(repr(self.signature))
1209        args.append(f"inputs=[{', '.join(map(repr, self.inputs))}]")
1210        args.append(f"shape_out={self.shape_out}")
1211        return f"Function({', '.join(args)})"
1212
1213    def depends_on(self, x: "Variable") -> bool:
1214        return any(t.depends_on(x) for t in self.inputs)
1215
1216    def _substitute(self, x: "Variable", y: "Tensor") -> "Tensor":
1217        return Function(self.signature, [t.substitute(x, y) for t in self.inputs], self.shape_out)

A tensor that represents a function applied to one or more input tensors.

Attributes: signature: The FunctionSignature for this function. inputs: A list of input tensors. shape_out: A dictionary mapping output edge names to sizes.

Function( signature: FunctionSignature, inputs: Iterable[Tensor], shape_out: dict[str, sympy.core.symbol.Symbol]) 
1048    def __init__(
1049        self,
1050        signature: FunctionSignature,
1051        inputs: Iterable[Tensor],
1052        shape_out: dict[str, Symbol],
1053    ):
1054        """
1055        A function tensor that takes one or more input tensors and produces an output tensor.
1056
1057        Args:
1058            signature: The FunctionSignature defining this function, or a string giving the function name.
1059            inputs: The input tensors and their input edge names. [(t0, e00, e01, ...), (t1, e10, ...), ...]
1060            shape_out: The names of the output edges of this function.
1061        """
1062        self.shape_out = self._check_shape([], shape_out)
1063        self.inputs = list(inputs)
1064        self.signature = signature
1065
1066        # Validation
1067        if self.shape_out.keys() != signature.edges:
1068            raise ValueError(f"Signature doesn't match shape: {self.shape_out.keys()=} != {signature.edges}")
1069        if len(self.inputs) != len(signature.inputs):
1070            raise ValueError(f"Expected {len(signature.inputs)} inputs, got {len(self.inputs)}")
1071        for t, es in zip(self.inputs, signature.inputs):
1072            if es - t.edges:
1073                raise ValueError(f"Input edges {es} not subset of {t.edges=}")
1074
1075        # Build final shape = union of output edges + broadcast edges from each input
1076        # Note that this approach pushes all the broadcasted edges to the end of the shape.
1077        # But we don't care about the order of the edges, so it's fine.
1078        self._shape = dict(self.shape_out)
1079        # We allow "broadcasting" for edges that are not in fn_sig.inputs[i].
1080        # So if an input has edges that are not used, they're broadcasted.
1081        for t, es in zip(self.inputs, self.signature.inputs):
1082            # any edges in t.edges - es are "broadcast"
1083            broadcast_edges = t.edges - es
1084            if broadcast_edges & self._shape.keys():
1085                raise ValueError("Broadcast edges must not be shared between inputs")
1086            for b in broadcast_edges:
1087                self._shape[b] = t.shape[b]

class Derivative(Tensor): 
1220class Derivative(Tensor):
1221    """
1222    A tensor representing the derivative of another tensor with respect to a variable.
1223    """
1224
1225    def __init__(self, tensor: Tensor, wrt: Variable, new_names: Optional[dict[str, str]] = None):
1226        """
1227        A tensor representing the derivative of another tensor.
1228
1229        Args:
1230            tensor: The tensor to differentiate.
1231            x: The variable with respect to which to differentiate.
1232            new_names: A mapping for renaming edges (if not provided, it will be generated).
1233        """
1234        self.tensor = tensor
1235        self.x = wrt
1236        # If no edges were given, pick some names based on x, but avoid clashes with tensor.
1237        self.new_names = tensor._check_grad(wrt, new_names)
1238        self._shape = tensor.shape | {self.new_names[e]: wrt.shape[e] for e in wrt.edges}
1239
1240    def _simplify(self, args: dict[str, Any]) -> Tensor:
1241        if not self.tensor.depends_on(self.x):
1242            return Zero(**self.shape)
1243        inner = self.tensor.simplify(args)
1244        if args["grad_steps"] == 0:
1245            # If grad_steps is 0, we pass the simplify through the derivative.
1246            res = Derivative(inner, self.x, self.new_names)
1247        else:
1248            args["grad_steps"] -= 1
1249            # Have to call simplify twice to avoid an infinite loop when stacking multiple derivatives.
1250            res = inner.grad(self.x, self.new_names).simplify(args)
1251        return res
1252
1253    def _grad(self, x: Variable, new_names: dict[str, str]) -> Tensor:
1254        # To avoid an infinite loop, we let the grad pass through us, rather than creating a double derivative.
1255        return Derivative(self.tensor.grad(x, new_names), self.x, self.new_names)
1256
1257    def _rename(self, **kwargs: str) -> Tensor:
1258        # The free edges of Derivative are both the free edges of self.tensor and the new_names.
1259        # This is the only place where we need to rename the "internal edges" of the tensor.
1260        return Derivative(
1261            self.tensor.rename(**kwargs),
1262            self.x,
1263            {o: kwargs.get(e, e) for o, e in self.new_names.items()},
1264        )
1265
1266    def structural_graph(self) -> tuple[nx.MultiDiGraph, dict[str, int]]:
1267        G = nx.MultiDiGraph()
1268        G.add_node(0, name="Derivative", tensor=self)
1269        edges = {}
1270        # We add a node for the "wrt" tensor
1271        # and connect new_edges to point to the respective edges in self.x
1272        G, x_edges = _add_structural_graph(G, self.x, root_edge_label="self.x")
1273        edges |= {e: x_edges[oe] for oe, e in self.new_names.items()}
1274        # Then we add the differentiated tensor
1275        G, t_edges = _add_structural_graph(G, self.tensor, root_edge_label="self.tensor")
1276        edges |= t_edges
1277        assert edges.keys() == self.edges
1278        return G, edges
1279
1280    def __repr__(self) -> str:
1281        return f"Derivative({self.tensor}, {self.x}, {self.new_names})"
1282
1283    def depends_on(self, x: "Variable") -> bool:
1284        return self.tensor.depends_on(x)

class Product(Tensor): 
1292class Product(Tensor):
1293    """
1294    A tensor representing the product (contraction) of several tensors.
1295    """
1296
1297    def __init__(self, factors: Iterable[Tensor]):
1298        """
1299        Initialize a Product tensor.
1300
1301        Args:
1302            factors: An iterable of tensors to be multiplied/contracted.
1303        """
1304        self.factors = list(factors)
1305        self._shape = {}
1306        for edge, ts in _group_edges(self.factors).items():
1307            if len(ts) == 1:
1308                self._shape[edge] = ts[0].shape[edge]
1309            elif len(ts) == 2:
1310                s1, s2 = [t.shape[edge] for t in ts]
1311                if s1 != s2:
1312                    raise ValueError(f"Edge {edge} has different sizes, {s1} != {s2}")
1313            else:
1314                raise ValueError(
1315                    f"edge {edge} had multiplicity {len(ts)}. Use an identity tensor to combine multiple edges."
1316                )
1317
1318    def _rename(self, **kwargs: str) -> Tensor:
1319        # Rename the inner edges (contractions) to avoid the new names introduced
1320        # by the renaming of the free edges.
1321        new_names = {kwargs.get(e, e) for e in self.edges}
1322        contractions = {e for t in self.factors for e in t.edges} - self.edges
1323        # Note the `unused_edge_names` function avoids introducing new clashes
1324        # between the edges being renamed.
1325        rename = _unused_edge_names(contractions, new_names)
1326        # It's safe to add the kwargs to rename, since self._check_rename restricts kwargs to only
1327        # contain keys that are in self.edges.
1328        rename |= kwargs
1329        return Product([t.rename(**rename) for t in self.factors])
1330
1331    @staticmethod
1332    def merge(products: list["Product"]) -> "Product":
1333        """
1334        Merge several Product tensors into one, renaming inner edges so they are distinct.
1335
1336        Args:
1337            products: A list of Product tensors.
1338
1339        Returns:
1340            A new Product tensor merging the inputs.
1341        """
1342        used_edges = {e for p in products for e in p.edges}
1343        res = []
1344        for p in products:
1345            # Maybe this could also be expressed in terms of avoid_internal_edges
1346            inner_edges = {e for t in p.factors for e in t.edges if e not in p.edges}
1347            rename = _unused_edge_names(inner_edges, used_edges)
1348            for t in p.factors:
1349                res.append(t.rename(**rename))
1350            used_edges.update(rename.values())  # Later renames should not clash with this one
1351        return Product(res)
1352
1353    def _grad(self, x: Variable, new_names: dict[str, str]) -> Tensor:
1354        # Since we are adding new edges to an internal tensor in the product, we need to make sure
1355        # none of the other tensors in the product have edges that clash with these new edges.
1356        inner_names = {e for t in self.factors for e in t.edges if e not in self.edges}
1357        new_edges = set(new_names.values()) | self.edges
1358        rename = _unused_edge_names(inner_names, new_edges)
1359        new_prod = Product([t.rename(**rename) for t in self.factors])
1360        assert new_prod.shape == self.shape, "Renaming should not change the product"
1361
1362        # The classic product rule of Calculus: d/dx (f * g) = f' * g + f * g'
1363        return Sum(
1364            [
1365                Product(new_prod.factors[:i] + [Derivative(t, x, new_names)] + new_prod.factors[i + 1 :])
1366                for i, t in enumerate(new_prod.factors)
1367            ]
1368        )
1369
1370    def _substitute(self, x: "Variable", y: "Tensor") -> "Tensor":
1371        return Product([t.substitute(x, y) for t in self.factors])
1372
1373    def __repr__(self) -> str:
1374        if len(self.factors) <= 1:
1375            return f"Product({self.factors})"
1376        else:
1377            inner = "    " + ",\n    ".join(map(repr, self.factors)) + ","
1378            return f"Product([\n{inner}\n])"
1379
1380    def _simplify(self, args: dict[str, Any]) -> Tensor:
1381        tensors = [t.simplify(args=args) for t in self.factors]
1382
1383        # If any tensor in a product is 0, so is the whole product
1384        if any(isinstance(t, Zero) for t in tensors):
1385            return Zero(**self.shape)
1386
1387        # Decide whether to push products through sums. This can be useful to simplify networks for
1388        # presentation, but it can also blow up the number of terms. So we make it optional.
1389        if args.get("distributed_products", False):
1390            raise NotImplementedError("Not implemented yet")
1391
1392        # Combine nested products. Note that not combining products may be useful to keep the
1393        # "natural" contraction order. This can speed up evaluation, since sub-tensors can be reused.
1394        if args["associative_products"]:
1395            sub_products = [t if isinstance(t, Product) else Product([t]) for t in tensors]
1396            tensors = Product.merge(sub_products).factors
1397
1398        # We can do a "small" kind of distributed products, which is handling children that are single sums
1399        # Also, if a child is a sum with a single element, we can pull the weight up.
1400        # In general, we can pull out the least common multiple of the weights of the children.
1401        if single_sums := [t for t in tensors if isinstance(t, Sum) and len(t.terms) == 1]:
1402            tensors = [t if t not in single_sums else t.terms[0] for t in tensors]
1403            res_weight = math.prod(t.weights[0] for t in single_sums)
1404        else:
1405            res_weight = 1
1406
1407        def verify_edges(ts: list[Tensor], msg: str = "") -> None:
1408            cnt = Counter(e for t in ts for e in t.edges)
1409            assert not cnt or cnt.most_common()[0][1] <= 2, msg
1410
1411        # Simplify Delta Tensors
1412        verify_edges(tensors)
1413        tensors = Delta.simplify_outer(tensors)
1414        verify_edges(tensors)
1415
1416        # Combine / Cancel Product Functions
1417        if args["combine_products"]:
1418            from tensorgrad.functions import _PowerFunction
1419
1420            verify_edges(tensors)
1421            before = tensors
1422            tensors = _PowerFunction.simplify_outer(tensors, args)
1423            verify_edges(tensors, f"{before} -> {tensors}")
1424
1425        # Base cases
1426        if len(tensors) == 1:
1427            res = tensors[0]
1428        elif args["expand"]:
1429            terms = [[]]
1430            weights = [1]
1431            for t in tensors:
1432                if isinstance(t, Sum):
1433                    # Create cartesian product
1434                    terms = [term + [t0] for term in terms for t0 in t.terms]
1435                    weights = [w * w0 for w in weights for w0 in t.weights]
1436                else:
1437                    for term in terms:
1438                        term.append(t)
1439            # Recurse with expand=False to avoid infinite descent
1440            res = Sum([Product(ts) for ts in terms], weights).simplify(args={"expand": False})
1441        else:
1442            res = Product(tensors)
1443
1444        if res_weight != 1:
1445            res = res_weight * res
1446
1447        return res
1448
1449    def components(self) -> list["Product"]:
1450        """
1451        Decompose the product into disjoint components (subgraphs).
1452
1453        Returns:
1454            A list of Product tensors representing disjoint components.
1455        """
1456        # Create graph of tensor connections
1457        G = nx.Graph()
1458        G.add_nodes_from(range(len(self.factors)))
1459        for i, t1 in enumerate(self.factors):
1460            for j, t2 in enumerate(self.factors[i + 1 :], i + 1):
1461                if set(t1.edges) & set(t2.edges):
1462                    G.add_edge(i, j)
1463
1464        # Find connected components
1465        component_sets = list(nx.connected_components(G))
1466        components = [Product([self.factors[i] for i in comp]) for comp in component_sets]
1467        assert Product(components).edges == self.edges
1468        return components
1469
1470    def structural_graph(self) -> tuple[nx.MultiDiGraph, dict[str, int]]:
1471        G = nx.MultiDiGraph()
1472        G.add_node(0, name=self.__class__.__name__, tensor=self)
1473        edges = {}
1474        inner_edges = defaultdict(list)
1475        for t in self.factors:
1476            G, t_edges = _add_structural_graph(G, t)
1477            for e, node in t_edges.items():
1478                inner_edges[e].append(node)
1479        for e, nodes in inner_edges.items():
1480            if len(nodes) == 2:
1481                # Note that inner edges are bidirectional, since tensor products
1482                # are associative.
1483                n1, n2 = nodes
1484                G.add_edge(n1, n2)
1485                G.add_edge(n2, n1)
1486            else:
1487                # If the edge is only present once, it's an outer edge
1488                assert e in self.edges, f"{e} not in {self.edges}"
1489                (n1,) = nodes
1490                edges[e] = n1
1491        assert edges.keys() == self.edges
1492        return G, edges
1493
1494    def depends_on(self, x: "Variable") -> bool:
1495        return any(t.depends_on(x) for t in self.factors)
1496
1497    def _to_einsum_eq(self) -> tuple[list[Tensor], str]:
1498        """
1499        Convert the product to an einsum equation.
1500
1501        The main utility is that Delta tensors are mostly removed in favor of hyper edges, which are more efficient to compute.
1502        However, some Deltas are still needed, so we return the list of tensors that should be
1503        used with the einsum equation.
1504
1505        Returns:
1506            A tuple (factors, equation) where factors is a list of tensors and
1507            equation is the corresponding einsum string.
1508
1509        Raises:
1510            ValueError: If there are too many unique edges.
1511        """
1512        unique_edges = {e for t in self.factors for e in t.edges}
1513        if (n := len(unique_edges)) > 52:
1514            raise ValueError(f"Too many unique edges ({n} > 52) to convert to einsum equation")
1515        name_to_idx = defaultdict(lambda: ascii_letters[len(name_to_idx)])
1516
1517        # The main challenge is to convert Delta tensors to hyper edges
1518        factors = []
1519        for ft in self.factors:
1520            if isinstance(ft, Delta) and ft.order >= 1:
1521                output_edges = ft.edges & self.edges
1522                input_edges = ft.edges - output_edges
1523                # However, einsum doesn't support duplicated indices in the output, like i->ii,
1524                # So we need to recreate some Delta tensors manually
1525                if len(input_edges) >= 1:
1526                    e0 = list(input_edges)[0]
1527                    if len(output_edges) <= 1:
1528                        for e in ft.edges:
1529                            name_to_idx[e] = name_to_idx[e0]
1530                    if len(output_edges) > 1:
1531                        for e in input_edges:
1532                            name_to_idx[e] = name_to_idx[e0]
1533                        compressed_delta = Delta(ft._size, e0, *output_edges)
1534                        factors.append(compressed_delta)
1535                else:
1536                    factors.append(ft)
1537            else:
1538                factors.append(ft)
1539
1540        equation = ",".join("".join(name_to_idx[e] for e in ft.edges) for ft in factors)
1541        equation += "->" + "".join(name_to_idx[e] for e in self.edges)
1542        return factors, equation

A tensor representing the product (contraction) of several tensors.

Product(factors: Iterable[Tensor]) 
1297    def __init__(self, factors: Iterable[Tensor]):
1298        """
1299        Initialize a Product tensor.
1300
1301        Args:
1302            factors: An iterable of tensors to be multiplied/contracted.
1303        """
1304        self.factors = list(factors)
1305        self._shape = {}
1306        for edge, ts in _group_edges(self.factors).items():
1307            if len(ts) == 1:
1308                self._shape[edge] = ts[0].shape[edge]
1309            elif len(ts) == 2:
1310                s1, s2 = [t.shape[edge] for t in ts]
1311                if s1 != s2:
1312                    raise ValueError(f"Edge {edge} has different sizes, {s1} != {s2}")
1313            else:
1314                raise ValueError(
1315                    f"edge {edge} had multiplicity {len(ts)}. Use an identity tensor to combine multiple edges."
1316                )

@staticmethod
def merge(products: list[Product]) -> Product: 
1331    @staticmethod
1332    def merge(products: list["Product"]) -> "Product":
1333        """
1334        Merge several Product tensors into one, renaming inner edges so they are distinct.
1335
1336        Args:
1337            products: A list of Product tensors.
1338
1339        Returns:
1340            A new Product tensor merging the inputs.
1341        """
1342        used_edges = {e for p in products for e in p.edges}
1343        res = []
1344        for p in products:
1345            # Maybe this could also be expressed in terms of avoid_internal_edges
1346            inner_edges = {e for t in p.factors for e in t.edges if e not in p.edges}
1347            rename = _unused_edge_names(inner_edges, used_edges)
1348            for t in p.factors:
1349                res.append(t.rename(**rename))
1350            used_edges.update(rename.values())  # Later renames should not clash with this one
1351        return Product(res)
